South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.

div.head: A MILITARY SCANDAL
div.p: The Report of the Royal Commission on War Stores in South Africa is not only in itself a very painful document but it cannot fail to arouse serious misgivings as to matters which did not fall within the purview of the Commissioners. It is bad enough to be told that the total preventable loss to the home taxpayer during the 22 months after the Peace lies somewhere between three-quarters of a million sterling and one and a quarter million sterling. But the real sting of the Report to our mind (says the "Globe") consists of the general impeachment of the foresight and business capacity of the implicated officials, civil and military. The Commissioners have placed on record incidentally their conviction that no private firm could avoid bankruptcy if it allowed its agents to deal with business matters in the mode in which certain officers of high rank in the Army Service Corps have dealt with the purchase and sale of supplies. The same reflection is forced upon the reader of the Report, only with a much wider and. more universal application. If an Empire like ours cannot get better yalue out of its servants, and cannot exact a higher standard of ability and integrity, the day of decline and fall cannot be very far distant. On the general question of corruption, indeed, the Commissioners do not find that the, sweeping innuendos of Sir William Butler and his colleagues have any solid foundation in fact. Certain officers and non-commissioned, officers have gravely misconducted themselves, and their fate is left to the military authority A censure, severe, but, in our judgment hardly severe enough, is passed upon Colonel Morgan: it is all the more to be deplored when the Commissioners admit that officer to be a man of exceptional capacity in the Army Service Corps whose career had been one of rapid and deserved success. It is very unpleasant, als, to find that the Army Service. Corps regulations forbidding social inter course with contractors were habitually disregarded by officials holding positions of great responsibility. The Army Service Corps emerges from the inquiry with a heavy stain on what had been a brilliant record, and its personnel will require a drastic purging

But, as we have said before, the main interest of the inquiry lies in its revelations of the incapacity of the Military authorities and of the War Office to deal with a situation which must have been foreseen months before it actually took shape. All through the spring of 1902 it was patent to those in authority that the Boer resistance was weakening, that the end might come at any moment, and that a prodigious amount of Army stores would have to be disposed of. Lord Kitchener, indeed, had made provision for winding up the financial side of the war by appointing Major Armstrong as Financial Adviser to the General Officer Commanding-in-Chief; and the ink was scarcely dry on the Vereeniging treaty when he created the sales department for taking over all surplus stores, and entrusted its organization to Colonel Morgan, who, up to that date, was fully deserving of the confidence of his superiors. Unhappily, Lord Kitchener left Africa almost immediately after the war was at an end, and from that date chaos ensued. The South African military command was divided into three, but through an omission, the responsibility of which is not travel, Major Armstrong was given no place in the reconstruction. And thus a post which Lord Kitchener considered of vital importance during the critical period of demobilization and the disposal of supplies and stores was left in abeyance. Worse than this, the detailed arrangement, administrative and financial, necessary for carrying the division of the command into practical working operation" seems to have altogether escaped the attention of the Quartermaster General's department for nearly three months, while the Finance Department of the War Office issued no instructions at all. One step, however, was taken towards the end of August. Orders came out from England recalling Colonel Morgan, and appointing Colonel Hipwell as Director of Supplies in his place. This substitution was not due to any distrust of Colonel Morgan, but to a mere pedantic adhesion to the principles of seniority, regardless of experience and capacity. The Commissioners acquit Colonel Hipwell of direct misconduct, but they make their opinion of his unfitness for the post perfectly apparent.

Among the consequences of Colonel Morgan's recall was the enormous loss sustained by the working of the local contract system. It was originally devised by him with the approval of Lord Kitchener, and entailed the disposal on the spot of the surplus stores to local ontractors, and their re-purchase from time to time without drawing fresh supplies from home. Under an exceptionally capable officer it might possibly have succeeded, though the odds are strongly against it; and when once the fatal entanglements with Meyer (Limited) had been entered into, its fate was sealed. Colonel Morgan was largely, but not solely, responsible for this arrangement, and his conduct in getting a highly-paid berth in that concern for his brother was most censurable. Had he remained at the head of affairs, his knowledge and ability might have checked some of the grosser abuses, but Colonel Hipwell was a child in the hands of the Philistines. He had not devised the system of local contracts, and had had no part in its recommendation, But he and his subordinate, Captain Limond, not only accepted it without examination or protest, but with a whole-hearted devotion worthy of a better cause they strove to give the system the appearance of a working concern, "they sacrificed public money, abandoned legal rights and equitable claims, and by continual subsidy and concession, succeeded in giving to the contractors a false semblance of activity." The miserable story of the contractors and their victims, of the criminal carelessness of some officers, of the incredible recklessness of others, was told in the daily reports of evidence taken before the Commission. The real guilt lies with those who allow so vital a department of the Army to be improperly, and insufficiently staffed, and with the War Office clerks in the finance department ar home, who neglected the whole series of transactions in South Africa, and resented all efforts at inquiry. One of these, a worthy successor of Tite Barnacle in "Little Dorrit," suggested that if the Controller and Auditor-General persisted in his inquiries he should be "told to mind his own business." The Coar missioners have also to complain of the carelessness and indifference of the military authorities in South Africa, and it is apparent that the inquiries prosecuted under their directions in the sub-Continent met with ill-disguised obstruction. The Commissioners have discharged a most difficult and invidious task in at manner commensurate with their high reputation

div.head: Fatal Train Accident.
div.p: A native was ran over by a train at Matarieh yesterday and killed on the spot.

div.head: Sudan Crop Prospects.
div.p: The Sudan Times" says that the crop prospects around Khartoum are excellent.

div.head: San Stefano Theatre.
div.p: The French comedy company will make ita debut at this theatre to-night, with Bonbouroche.

div.head: Quarantine in Italy
div.p: Arrivals from Alexandria in Italian ports are now subjected to a medical inspection and disinfection.

div.head: Imperial Birthday
div.p: On the occasion of the 79th anniversary of the birth of the Emperor-King Francis-Joseph, the Bank of Salonics will be closed on Saturday.

div.head: Salda Zeynab Mouled.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has decided to allow the mouled of Saida Zeynab, in Cairo, to be held for ten days, beginning from the 25th inst.

div.head: Charbleh Agricultural Show
div.p: The Agricultural Show of the Gharbieh Moadirieh will be opened on the 11th October next. A large number of agriculturists are making preparations for the exhibition.

div.head: Horse Electrocuted
div.p: A cart-horse was electrocuted on Sunday morning in Cairo between Bab el-Khalk and the Citadel, by the snapping of the electric wire of the Boulac Citadel tramway line..

div.head: Dakhalch Markaz.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has granted a credit of L.R. 1,365 to cover the cost of estab lishing and maintaining a markaz in the Oasis of Dakhaleb, to be founded next year.

div.head: Police Scandals
div.p: Two officers of the Alexandria City Police are to be brought before a council of discipline, consisting of the Sub Governor, the Hakimdar, and Mr. Hornblower, Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior,

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: We may remind our readers that the performance to be given at the Alhambra this evening is for the benefit of the Comitato Pro Libertate Rusia. The programme includes L'Artiglio and Il Carnevale di Torino.

div.head: Murder Will Out.
div.p: In connection with the murder of a Maltese woman in Clot Bey-street, Cairo, last month, one of the Berbereen who committed it has been arrested in a village in Upper Egypt. Robbery was the motive of the crime.

div.head: Base Coin.
div.p: The Cairo police have arrested a private of the XIV. Battalion on the charge of uttering false money. On searching his pockets, a quantity of the false coin was found on him. An inquiry has been opened by the authorities.

div.head: Fatal Quarrel.
div.p: Our Akhmin Correspondent reports that in the course of a quarrel between two inhabitants of the village of Galawin over the boundaries of their land, one of the men struck the other with a piece of wood, which caused injuries that proved fatal.

div.head: Cairo Motor Facility.
div.p: The lady who was on a motor in the company of the Moudir of Keneh, Yessim Bay Mustapha, and met her death in the accident that ensued, is said not to have been the wife of that official. The Parquet has opened an inquiry into the fatality. The chauffeur is expected to recover.

div.head: Mex-Les-Sains.
div.p: Mex continues to attract large crowds of Alexandriana in search of cocl, health giving ozone, and the management of the casino are not bébindhand in providing attractions for their clients. Two bands are constantly in attendance, and we are informed that a variety company will make its debut there in a few days.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: During the week ending last Saturday fifteen cases of plague were reported, according to the report used by the Department of Public Health, I notified in Egypt, eight of which occurred at Alexandria, five at Saiz, and two at Port Said. Ten deaths were recorded and the number resigning under treatment on that data was twelve. From the 1st of January 419 cases have in all been notified, as compared with 221 and 765 in the corresponding periods of 1905) and 1934 respectively.

div.head: New Employment Registry
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members! requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. Advt.]

div.head:
KING AND EGYPT
LORD CROMER EXPLAINS
THE CAPITULATIONS
MODIFICATION IMMINENT
GERMANY'S INTERESTS IN EGYPT
"NO BARGAINING"
div.p: LONDON, Wednesday, August 15. In the course of a recent audience granted by the King to Lord Cromer the position of affairs in Egypt was fully gone into. His lordship acquainted his Majesty with the principles of the Government working, pointing out the reforms that are necessary to the improvement of Egypt's condition, more especially the anomalies arising from the existence of the Capitulations. I understand that Germany is fully in accord with the other European nations, as to the advisability of modifying there in the interest of all concerned. The suggestion that the Kaiser wiil at to-day's interview with King Edward suggest any bargaining is outside the mark. There is every reason to believe that the scheme formulated in Lord Cromer's last annual Report, as to modifying the Capitulations, will shortly take shape with a view to obtaining the consent of the countries interest- ed and with the object of putting the proposed reforms into execution with as little delay as possible. It is realized that German interests in the Capitulations are no greater than those of the smallest European nation, and there can be no question of any bargaining.

div.head: Germany and Egypt.
div.p: The "Times" publishes the following telegram from Berlin: Ever since the settlement of the Akabah dispute, and more particularly since the Denish- wai incident, British policy in Egypt has been persistently subjected by the German Press to malicious and ill-informed criticism. The pree cautionary measures which the British Government has seen fit to adopt in view of the restlessaners and unsettled feeling in Egypt have been interpreted as the first step towards the overthrow of the Capitulations. Lord Cromer's proposals for the amelioration of administrative and judicial conditions have been similarly misconstrued. Upon the strength of these misrepresentations it has been suggested that Egypt should be made the subject of international discussion, and that in compensation for waiving her rights under the Capitulations) Germany should receive sole control over the proposed terminus of the Baghdad Railway. In the circumstances, Sir Edward Grey's statement in the House of Commons on Saturday week that there is no intention of converting Egypt into a British Crown Colony or of handing it over to Turkish administration will have a salutary effect. It is not without significance that in its report of Saturday's debate the German semi-official Telegraph Agency ignored this portion of the Foreign Secretary's speech but his words will nonetheless be understood in those quarters in Berlin and in Cairo which are responsible for these maneuvers.

div.head: WHERE IS THE KING.
div.p: The Schloss Friedrichshof, where King Edward and the Kaiser met yesterday, is situated on a beautiful declivity of a hill near Cronberg, on the Homburg road. Thick masses of pines grow on the hills behind it, and in front are the charming vineyards and fields of Cronberg, with the smoke of Frankfort away on the horizon. Friedrichshof was bought by the Empress Friedrich in 1888, and has been greatly enlarged and beautified. It was here this terribly tried Princess lived the last mournful years of her life. At her death the castle came into possession of Princess Margarete of Hesse, the youngest daughter of Empress Friedrich. It is Princess Margarete and her husband, Princo. Ladwig of Hesse, who are the host and hostess of King Edward and the Kaiser.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.

div.head:
FRANCO-TURKISH DISPUTE.
EXPEDITION TO DJANET COUNTERMANDED
NEGOTIATIONS PROCEEDING SATISFACTORILY
Gazette's Special Service
div.p: The negotiations between the Sublime Porte and the French Ambassador at Constantinople in regard to the question of Tripoli are proceeding satisfactorily. The Sultan has sent instructions to the Governor of Tripoli to suspend the preparations that are being made for a military expedition to Djanet. Everything points to a speedy solution of the difficulty.

div.head:
M.P.'S TO VISIT EGYPT.
A "PERSONALLY CONDUCTED" TOUR.
div.p: It is rumoured that a number of Members of Parliament will pay a special visit to Egypt in the course of the coming season for the purpose of studying the actual conditions of the country on the spot. It is believed that these gentlemen, whose identity it is not difficult to guess, will be under the patronage of Mustapha Pasha Kamel. I It is not known whether they will be the guests of the Pashs during their trip. Great results are expected from the information which these gentlemen. will glean as to the exact state of things in Egypt, and it is confidently anticipated that startling developments will eventually result from their pronouncements in Parliament on their return home. The rumor that Messrs. Keir Hardie, Byles. Robertson, and Dillon will belong to this distinguished "personally conducted" party is unconfirmed..

div.head: DEATH OF COL. McKINSTRY.
div.p: We greatly regret to announce the death of Colonel A. W. McKinstry, an officer who was well known in Alexandria, where he gained much popularity while in command of the Leicestershire Regiment. Col. McKinstry, who was commandant of the Duke of York's Royal Military School, Chelsea, died suddenly last Wednesday evening, at the school, of heart failure, at the age of 53. He obtained his first commission in 1875 in the 102nd Peot, and was transferred to the 17th Foot (the Leicestershire Kegt.) in January, 1876. He served with the 5th Punjab Infantry with the Kabal Field Force in the Kuram Valley during the Afghan War of 1878-1879, and took part in the battle of Charasiah on October 7, 1879, and in the subsequent occupation of Kabal, receiving the medal with clasp for his services. Becoming a captain in March, 1883, he was an adjutant of Volunteers from September 1886, till September, 1889, and reaching the rank of major in September 1890, was lien- tenant-colonel of the Leicesterabire Regt. from November, 198, till November, 1909. He received the brevet rank of colonel in November, 1902, was appointed a regimental district colonel in April, 1903, and commandant of the Dake of York's Royal Military School the following September.

div.head: THE LATE CHERIF PASHA.
div.p: The mortal remains of the late Cherif Pasha arrive here from France on Tuesday for burial. Daring his last illness, the Pasha was visited twice by the Khedive, and frequently by Prince Mohamed Aly. Cherif Pasha expired in the arms of Dr. Comanos Pasha. On being informed of the death, the Khedive gave orders to Sheikh Mohamed Osman to perform the customary rite of washing the body, and instructed Moharrem Pasha Shahin to convey his condolences to the mother of the deceased. Cherif Pasha had many Egyptian decorations, and was an officer of the Legion or Honour. He bequeathed the third of his estate to his wife.

div.head: THE FASHN TRAGEDY
div.p: The inquiry which has been opened by the Minieh authorities into the circumstances of the murder of the station-master and pointsman at Fashn, which took took place a few weeks ago, shows that it was committed by tour Bedouins, who had been incited by Abd. el-Kadir, son of Lamloum Bey el-Saadi, the Omdeh of the Fawaid tribe. The criminals have all been arrested; and Lamloum Bey has been suspended from the omdehship. The official report gives the following account of the murder: Shortly before the crime was committed, Abdel-Kadir betook himself to a public house at Pashn, which the Moa dirieh had placed "out of bounds," and the head ghaffire resorted to strict measures to bring him out. Abdel Kadir became greatly enraged and threatened the ghaffir that be would put him in a spare. He accordingly called four of his Bedouin followers and, filling their pockets with money, ordered them to go and kill the station-master and the pointsman, with a view to getting the ghaffir suspected of the murder, bat the plot failed.

div.head:
DISCORD AT RAFAH.
BOUNDARY COMMISSIONERS DISAGREE.
NO PROGRESS MADE.
Gazette's Special Service
div.p: PARIS, Wednesday August 15. A telegram from Jaffa to the "Echo de Paris", says that the members of the Turco- Egyptian Boundary Commission have fallen into complete discord over certain important points. The result is that the situation is exactly the same as it was before the conflict between the two countries. Our Constantinople Correspondent writes:- According to a rumour among circles which are ordinarily well-informed, serious disagree ments have cropped up over the differences which have hindered from the star the nego tiations for the delimitation of the Sinai boundary. To-day these negotiations clash over the question as to whether the three oases which are situated at the starting point of the line of demarcation should tall to Egypt or to Turkey. These oases incontestably belong to Egypt, but the Turks are now claiming them.

div.head: GERMAN INFLUENCE IN TURKEY
div.p: The progress of German influence in Turkey is directed by M. Jean Rodes, the Special Correspondent of the ' Bolair at Constantinople. M. Rodes comes to the conclusion that, though Germany has acquired greater material interests in Turkey than England possesses(excluding Egypt). These interests are still inferior to those of Prance. Statistics of the railways, the chief factor of German penetration, show that France holds 1,553 kilomètres, Germany 1,453, and Austria 1,205. England has only 516. The Germans managed to purchase a large block of shares in the Austrian line on the death of Baron Hirsch, but the greater part of the capital is in French hands. Undoubtedly the Baghdad Railway would change the present state of things to the advantage of Germany, but when it is remembered that an appeal had to be made to the French capital to construct the first section, it may be doubted whether the line will be finished for many years to come. It can hardly be supposed that the assistance given by Preach financiers, with the approval of the will be continued indefinitely in view of the change in French policy and the strongly political aspect of the railway enterprise in question. M. Rodes quotes an official in charge of one of the principal Turkish lines as stating that the kilomètric guarantee for the existing section is very inadequate. The Turkish Government has to meet a deficit of 13,631 fr. per kilomètre. The surplus of the Anatolian Railway receipts is being used for this purpose, but it is evident that such an expedient would be impracticable for the whole railway, though it may serve for one section. The only source of revenue yet discovered for enabling the line to be continued, with the necessary guarantee, is the proposed increase of 3 per cent, in the Customs tariff; but this surplus is claimed for the Ottoman Public Debt and for the reforms in Macedonia. Under these circumstances it may be affirmed that the Baghdad Railway will not be completed for at least sixty years, if at all. M. Rodes thinks that German influence in Turkey is on the wane. Germany's attitude over the seizure of one of her steamships caused great irritation; and Turkish officials observe that Germany's friendship has not averted the humiliations undergone by the Porte.

div.head: HON. HAROLD HAWKE'S WEDDING.
div.p: St. Mary's Churob, Bryanston-square, was this day week the scene of the quiet wedding of Capt. the Hon. Harold Brooke Hawke, Leicestershire Regiment, son of the late Rev. Lord Hawke, and brother of the present Peer (the popular captain of the Yorkshire cricket XI.), and Mrs. Arthur Bamford, widow of Mr. Arthur Bamford, of Misterton, Leicestershire, and daughter of the late Mr. John Nash, of Chicago and Worcester. The Rev. Arthar Carter, rector of Brooksby, Leicster, performed the ceremony, and Mr. 8. J. Waring, jan, gave the bride away. She wore a costume of fine cream c'oth trimmed with cream braid, and a straw hat worked in a design of pink roses, and adorned with white feathers. She also wore some beautiful pearl and diamond ornaments, and carried a bouquet of dark red roses. Lord Hawke supported his brother as best man, and among the relations and friends present at the church were Capt. the Hon. Stanhope Hawke, RN, the Hon. Eleanor Hawke, the Hon. Alice Hawke, Mrs. Barridge, Mrs. Catchpole, Mrs. Walter Bary, Miss Constance Bary, Mr. and Mrs. P. Parry-Jones, Dr. and Mrs. Cornett, Mrs. Tew, Mrs. Walker and Miss Walker, Dr., and Mrs. Scott, Miss Griffin, Miss Bamford, and Mr. Scott Bamford. The wedding party afterwards met at the Hotel Great Central, and later Capt. and Mrs. Hawke left for a short honeymoon tour before returning to town.

div.head: THE PERSIAN CONSTITUTION.
div.p: A number of Turkish writers and notables met in Cairo on Tuesday evening and despatched a telegram to the Shah of Persia congratulating his Majesty and his nation on be establishment of a Constitution in Persia.

div.head:
THE SERSINA AFFAIR.
THE IDEMNITY RUMOUR.
div.p: We understand that there is no truth in the statements which have appeared in the columns of several of our contemporaries concerning the payment of an indemnity to the family of the native who was found dead at Sersina on the afternoon of the Denishwai incident, and who, it was alleged, was killed by a soldier of the party which was sent out by Captain Bostock. The papers to which we refer remarked that an English officer, accompanied by an inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, went to Sereina to pay an indemnity to the dead man's family. We are able to atste, however, that the only recent occasion on which an officer of the Army of Occupation has visited Sersion accompanied by an inspector of the Ministry of the Interior was at the time of the inquiry made by the Parquet into the affair, when, in accordance with the request of that Ministry, Captain Somerville was appointed to represent the Army of Occupation, and was accompanied by Mr. Moberly. As is already known, no evidence at all was forthcoming that the man had been killed by one of the relief party, and it can therefore be safely assumed that in the absence of any such evidence an indemnity would be paid.

div.head:
EX-ARMY OFFICER'S EXPLOITS.
SENTENCED TO 3 MONTHS' PRISON.
div.p: Ahmed Effendi Pahmi Zagloug, an ex-officer of the Egyptian Army, who was recently, charged with indecently approaching a young French lady, has been sentenced to threa months' imprisonment and a fine of £50. It will be remembered by most of our readers that, on the occasion to which we refor, M. Albert Samama went into a shop in the Tewfikieh district of Cairo and that his sister, who remained outside, was subjected to gross insults by Ahmed Zaglong, also that when her brother returned and remonstrated with the ex-officer, be, suffered considerably from the attack which was made upon him. We are glad to note that judgment has been rendered so speedily and that the punishmeat "fite the crime."

div.head: THE BUILDING LANDS OF EGYPT, LTD.
div.p: There is to be an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Building Lands of Egypt, Limited, on the 4th September, when the various questions arising out of the hitch in the fusion with the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Limited, will be discussed. Fall details as to the meeting will be found in the formal notice in another column. Mr. Glymenopoulo is now at Brides-les- Bains, in the Savoy, and he may return to Egypt any day owing to the crisis in the fusion negotiations.

div.head: RAILWAY COLLISION
div.p: Our Damanbour Correspondent reports that on the morning of Tuesday a collision between two trains took place on the Delta Light Railway line at El-Messein station. While the up passenger train No. 1 was at the station, No.2 down train entered at full speed, and owing to the points not being properly set the trains collided with each other. Three passengers were injured, and damage was done to the trains. The scene after the collision was one of the greatest confusion, the large number of people who were traveling by the down train to Delingst market jumping out of their carriages and emitting loud cries of alarm.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. Prince Paad and Izzet Pasha left Carlsbad for St. Moritz last week. H.H. Prince Aziz's new yach', the Cabona, left Palermo for Messias yesterday week. The Earl and Countess of Cromer left Easton yesterday week for Falkirk. The rumoor is revived that Lord Kitchener, be who is alleged to be adamant against woman's larer, is inclined to marry. The story comes from India, and the lady's name is not mentioned; bat it it is trae, she will receive hearty congratulations on ber capture of the General Commanding. H.E. Bagan Sultan Mirzah Ali Ashar Khan, Pervian Consal General and Diplomatic Agent, has left Cairo for Constantinople, and during his absence will be replaced by Mohamed Fegib Bey, secretary to the Agency. Mr. P. H. Parker, District Jedge of Nicosia, Cyprus, is to act as Chief Justice on the departure of Sir Joseph Hutchinson for Ceylon, to which colony he has been promoted as the sacoessor of Sir Charles P. Layard, who has retired. Mr. Parker has been in Cyprus for the past sixteen years, and has served as President of the six District Courts of the Island, and has acted as Paisne Judge on three occasions. He was formerly connected with British Honduras, where he noted both as Attorney-General and as Chief Justice. He has been in the Colonial Civil Service for twenty-two years. Mrs. Walter Draper, whose sad bereavement of her little daughter we mentioned last week, sails with her niece this afternoon by the S.S. Seti for a stay in Scotland. Captain Dudley de Chair, RN., who is of the last election of honorary members of the R. Y. 8, acquired the useful knack of creating a favourable impression quite early in life. When he was a middy ashore in Egypt he got anapped up and conveyed a prisoner to Arabi Patha. He was such a nice boy that Arabi handed him over for safe custody to the ladies of the harem. He so delighted them that when the time came for the retorn of their captive there was a unanimous objection to letting him go. El Bimbashi T. G. Dalby, 3rd Battalion, has been struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army. The merchants of Kengh express antisfaction. with the action of Saba Pasha, Postmaster- General, in promoting to the first grade the postmaster at Keneh, who has proved during his long services to be an honest and a capable official.

div.head:
QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
RAPPORT DE SOLIMAN BEY ABANI
LA QUESTION DES ECHECHES
div.p: Dans sa séance da 3 juillet 1906, la Déléga tion a bien voulu me charger de rechercher les meilleurs moyens pour le transfert, eu des en- droits appropriés, des éohèches actuellement éparpillées sur plusieurs points de la ville. L'étude que j'ai faite de la question me permet de vous soumettre les observations et propositions suivantes: Les échèches ou, en d'autres termes, les habi tations rudimentaires pour les olasses pauvres indigènes se répartissent comme suit: 1 Les échèches de Gabbari; 2" les échèch s de Toabguish: 3° les échèches du Lazaret ou Chatby; 4 les 6 hèches de Ragheb pacha et de Gebel El Guella. -La Délégation a eu à s'occuper de ces dillé- rentes agglomérations et à pris en ce qui les concerne des décisions dont l'exécution a rencontré des obstacles de diverses natures. C'est ainsi que malgré que la Délégation ea le droit, en conformité de l'arrêté ministériel da 11 mai 1895, de prendre des décisions tendant à la fermeture de ces habitations en temps d'épidémier, ce Collège a estimé que l'adoption de pareilles mesures, sans assurer en même temps d'autres gites aux habitants des échèches, entrainersit des inconvénients plus grande que le maintien de ces échèches elles- mêmes, car elle aurait pour conséquence que les habitants des locaux contre lesquels les décisions de fermeture seraient prises, cherche- raient à se répandre au milieu des quartiers dont les habitations répondent aux conditions de l'hygiène et leur porteraient ainsi le tort le plus grave. Un exemple de cette situation a été fourni à la suite de la disparition desi 6ohèchos de Ras-el-Tine dont les habitants se sont répandas dans les quartiers environcants en trafoant avec eux la malpropreté qui les caractérise. Aussi la Délégation a t-elle pensé qu'avant de recourir à l'exercice des droits qai lai sont conférés, il y avait lieu pour elle de rechercher les emplacements auxquels les échèches pourraient être transférées en adoptant pour chaque agglomération les convenances de sos habitants. Les avantages de ce transtert sont incontestables; en effet, il permet de donner plus d'extension aux quartiers ch l'existence des échèches constituait un obstacle à leur développement; il permet à l'autorité sanitaire de prescrire dans les nouvelles babi- tations qui seront érigées toutes mesures d'by- giène et de propreté répondant aux exigences modernes, de telle sorte qu'on obtiendra ainsi la disparition d'an des dangers les plus grands qui menacent non seulement les habitants des échèches, mais aussi tous les habitants de la ville qui sont à la merci d'ane contagion que read plus facile la proximité de ces habitations malsaines. Ea dehors de ces deux avantages essentials, Is population musulmane de la ville a um intérêt direct important au transfert d'une partie des échèobes, soit celle de Toabgaich la zone occupée par ces échèches est en effem depuis longtemps réservée à l'élargissement du cimetière de la Colonne Pompée et on mi que tant que ce cimetière se trouvera à l'étroit comme il l'est actuellement, il sers impossible de remédier à l'état défectuerx où il se trouver et dont tout le monde se plaint. Pour toutes ces raisons la tâche dévolse à la Délégation consistant à assurer les moyens tendant au transfert des échèches et à leurs amélioration est une des plus importantes qei paissent s'imposer aux préoccupations d membres de ce Collège, car il s'agit non seule ment d'un boscin sanitaire à satisfaire, mais sassi d'an devoir social que les honorab'e- membres auront à coeur de remplir.

div.head:
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
div.p: Le Caire, 15 Août. Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé en reprise de 1/8 and 88 1/8 L'Unifiés a réactionné de 1/4 à 104 1/2. Ia National Bank a perda 1/8 à 26 1/4. L'Agri oole est restée invariée à 9 7/8, de même que la Deira à 16 7/8 et la Delta Light à 11 3/4 A Paris, l'action Crédit Poncier Egyptien est restée stationnaire à 756. La Banque d'Athènes a rétrogradé de 1 franc à 148. De même qu'hier, notre marché des valeurs s'est montré, ce matin, réactionnaire sur le valears qui ont récemment bénéficié d'une plus-value. Par contre, le cours de diver autres titres s'est sensiblement relevé. La National Bank a débuté aux abords de 26 3,16 pour fléchir en clôture à 26 1/16. L'Agricole a faibli à 9 3/4. Toujours en excellente tendance, la Casa di Soonto a progressé à 229 l'action ancienne et 218 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Athènes a été échangée à 148. L'action Crédit Poncier s'est raffermie à 760 et l'obligation à lots sacienne à 338 339. L'Immobilière a rétrogradé à 366. La Nile Land a reculé à 13 15/16 14, la Wardan Estate à 6 13/16-7,8 et les Improvements à 4 13/16-7/8. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été demandée à 4 1,8 3/16 et la part de fondateur à 69. La part de fondateur Agricole de Nil est revenue à 7 7/16 1/2. Les Héliopolis ont été négociés à 317 et la part de fondateur à 9 1/4. La Gharbieh a été traitée à 3 7/8; on allègue que, d'après une estimation récemment faite, la vente, sex prix sotuele, d'an peu plus de la moitié des terrains de cette Société suffirait presque à rembourser le capital actions qui se monte, comme on sait, ALB. 400.000. La part de fondateur Allotment and avancé à 128 et la part de dividende Ciments à 18. Les Jouissances Box du Caire se sent raffermies à 262 263. Los Automobiles ont rattrapé 1/8 à 512 Dans le groupe des valeurs bôtelièrer, les Nangovich ont encore réactionné à 15 7/8. E bonne tenne, les Egyptian ont avancé à 6 7/16- 1/2. Les Upper Egypt ont estaré à 4 7/8. L part de fondatear National Hotel a été rame née and 52 Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont faibli à 3 3/8 7/16. Les Estates ont été moins fermes à 1 19/16-7/8; par contre, la part de fondateur a été recherchée à 11 1/4 5/16. La Khedivial Mail a progressé à 33 sh. 6. Un journal d'Alexandrie s'est fait hier l'éch dan "brait de Bourse" suivant lequel la veute do Grand Continental Hotel aurait été conclue pour la somme de 600,000 livres. Or, on affirme que otte vieille rumeur, té éditée invariablement thage fois qu'an mon- vement se produit sur les titres de la Nango- vich Hotels Co. n'a toujours aucun fondement sérier x Nous détachons d'une lettre de Paris, arrivée par le courrier d'hier, les lignes suivantes: "Lal quidation de fin Juillet peat être mar quée d'une croix Loire dans les annales de notre Bourse, en raison des cours de compen sation qu'elle a fait enregistrer sur les fonds rus-es et spécialement sur le 5% nouveau de 1906. Il anflit de mettre en regard les derniers cours de compensation de ce fonds pour mesurer toute l'étendue de la baisse qu'il a sabie: le 31 Mai il compensait à 97, le 15 Jain à 90, le 30 Jnin à 88,25, le 15 Juillet à 84,60, eufia le 31 Juillet à 81,75. Ea deux mois la perte n'a pen été inférieure à 10 1/4 points. Et depuis la liquidation il est encore retombé à 78,50, ce qui fait un écart de 13 1/2 points avec le cours de compensation de fin Mai. Cette chute précipitée met en évidence la faate qui a été commise lors de l'émission de cet emprunt. Tout le poids en a été laissé à la spéculation, si bien qu'une grosia partie en est encore flottante, et dans les circonstances ac tuelles, elle ne trouvera pas facilement à se classer dans les portefeuilles." Les recettes des Tramways d'Alexandrie pour la semaine sa 10 Acât courant se sont élevées à L. E. 1,978 contre 1,736 en 1905, soit une augmentation de L. B. 242. Les recettes totales depuis le ler Janvier 1906 ont atteint Is somme de L E 47,925 contre 40,553, soit an surplus de L. B. 7,379 en faveur de l'exercice courant. Les recettes de l'Alexandris Ramleh Co. pour la semaine au 11 Août ee chiffrent par L. E. 1,671 contre 1,306 en 190", soit en plus- value de L. E. 365. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Octobre 1905 eat atteint L E. 52,737 contre 42,184 en 1905, avec une augmentation de L. B 1,551 pour l'exercice courant. Carnet de l'actionnaire. Les actionnaires de la Cassa di Soonto e di Risparmio sont informés qu'on dividender intérimaire pour l'exercice en cours, à raison de P. B 20 par action sur les titres des anciennes émissions, sera mis en paiement à partir de lundi prochain, 20 Ach, aux goi chete de cette Barque, à Alexandrie et su Caire, contre remise du coupon No. 38.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Le marché a débaté en pleine dépression sons l'effet de la baisse des cotons; mais ceux- ci s'étant relevés en e'otare, les valeurs ont également repris. Ea général, tontefuis, los cours finissent au-dessous de ceux d'hier.
Ce sont l'Agricole, la Ramaleb, la Cassa di Sconto, les Nangovich Hotels, a Delta Land et le Comptoir qui ont donné lieu au plos grand nombre de transactions.
Il faut y joindre la National Bank, la Ban qoe d'Athènes et l'Union Foncière.
On offre la National Bank à 26 1/16, La Barque d'Athènes à 147 3/4 et l'Urbaine à 6 3/32.
La Casa di Sconto réactionne à 227 l'an- cienne et 217 la nouvelle, le Comptoir à 6 3/4 la nouvelle, la part de fondateur à 44 et l'Union Poncière à 6 1/4.
Par contre l'Agricole reste ferme à 9 3/4, la Ramleh remonte à 7 3/16, les Nungovich à 17-1/6 et la Deita Land à 39/16.
APPEL DE FONDS.

Crédit Poncier Egyptien.-Deuxième quart sur les actions de la Société, soit 125 francs par titre, en denx versements égaux à effectuer, le premier du 1er au 6 Saptambre 1906 et le second da 2 an'8 Janvier 1907.

American Futures The Market this week has been somewhat more active, bat prions bave declined sharply, bo-day's closing values being 18 @ 10 points below those of last Thursday. The decline was chiefly due to the fall in prices in New York and New Orless, apon the publication of the Basess report, and to Mr. Price salling out his long interest. KING AND KAISER.
MEETING AT KRONBERG
RINGING OF JOYBELLS.
LONDON, August 15.

The newspapers make the meeting of the King and the Emperor William the occasion for reviews of the European political situation, especially in the Near East, where the legiti macy of Germany's influence and ambitions is admitted, but they deny that she has any "loons-standi" in Egypt, as claimed in the recent articles in the German prese. (Router)
CRONBERO, August 15.

The King has arrived here. He met the Emperor William, who was in military uniform and who welcomed him by kissing him on both obeeks. Their Majesties motored to Friedrichshof Castle amid the ringing of joybells. The Hon. Charles Hardinge accompanied the King, and the Foreign Minister, Herr Tschirschky, the Emperor William.
After refreshments at Friedrichshof the Sovereigns drove in open carriages to view the statue of the Emperor Frederick and then to the ancient Castle of Cronberg. They received ovations everywhere.
The Crown Prince of Greece lunched with their Majesties.
The royal party in the afternoon also visited Homburg, at King Edward's wish. (Reuter)
CRONBERG, August 15.
The Emperor William has received King Edward. The Sovereigns embraced each other and then left for the Castle of Friedrichshof. (Havas)

div.head: FIGHTING IN BULGARIA.
div.p: ATHENS IN MOURNING.
ATHENS, August 15.

According to a Bulgarian account, the fight-1 ing at Anchialos lasted from dawn till eight o'clock in the evening. Seven persons were killed. The number of wounded is unknown. It is admitted that most of the town has been burned. Athens is in mourning; the theatres are closed. A demonstration was made through the streets at midnight yesterday evening. (R.)
SOFIA, August 15.

A number of Greek families from Bulgaria are going to Salonika, và Servia, to escape the persecutions. Meanwhile, the Bulgarian Minister is taking strict measures to prevent farther disorders. It is believed here that the anti-Greek movement will soon end. (Reuter)

div.head: THE POPE'S ENCYCLICAL
div.p: PROBABLY COMPROMISE CHURCH'S FUTURE.
PARIS, August 15.

The consensus of opinion with regard to the Pope's Encyclical is that, it is calculated to gravely compromise the future of the Church of France. It is very much doubted whether the laymen are prepared to bear the expense of the maintenance of the Church, (Reuter) PARIS, August 15. The Bishops have begun to preach submis sion to the Pope's Encyclical. (Tavas)

div.head: TRANS SIBERIAN RAILWAY.
div.p: DISCOVERY OF FRAUDS..
ST. PETERSBURG, August 15.

An official enquiry, held at Tomek, disclosed the disappearance of 1,500 waggons, the property of the Trans-Siberian Railway, and frauds to the extent of £700,000 perpetrated at one station alone. (Reuter

Esst Denbigh Election. Mr. Hemmerde, the Liberal candidate, was elected with 5,917 votes in place of Mr. Moss, who was appointed to a judgeship. Mr. Boscawen, the Unionist candidate, had 3,126 votee."

div.head: ARABI PASHA.
div.p: In a little house up a by street of the Mohamedan quarter, old, friendless, broken, lives the man who might have ruled Egypt.

If you ask twenty people in Cairo to-day, "Where is Arabi Pasha?" fifteen will tell you that he is dead, while the other five do not know. In fact, after the bombardment of Alexandria, he was sent to exile for life in Ceylon, but was allowed, some four years ago, to return to his native city.

Tell your cabman to drive to "Beit Arabi Pasha," and he brings you triumphantly to the house where Arabi used to live, now the head-quarters of Christians, missionaries, and accursed of all good Mohamedans.

It was only after a week's hard ferreting that I discovered, through a native journalist, the whereabouts of the great man, and after much discussion at the outer gate we were admitted to the reception room, evidently at one time a fine apartment. But the carpet was worn, and the springs of the fine chairs were broken, their coverings torn, and the whole place spelt ruin. After a long wait, in which my hopes sank, the secretary returned to say that Arabi would see me, and soon after the man came in. This is the picture of him as I saw him.

Even now, in his seventieth year, he is a big man; in his prime he must have been immense. White hair and beard; a broad, thoughtful forehead, surmounted by the Turkish tarboosh; kindly eyes, dulled a little by age, but lighting up wonderfully when he talks about things which interest him; a straight, powerful nose; a large mouth, which must once have been hard and cruel, now softened by adversity. Though the day is warm he wears an overcoat, and he walks heavily on a massive ebony stick.

We begin in English with the customary inquiries, "How is your health and that of your family?" This topic exhausted, I am subject to a catechism as to the state of my health, the length of my stay, my married happiness, and my age.

Conversation languishes. I have drank my coffee, and be appears to wish me to go. I try him in French, but we get no further than the weather and the cotton crops, in which he would seem to take but a scant interest.

This will never do. My guide whispers, "He will not talk to day; we had better go." But I refuse. "Ask him in Arabic if he is rich and happy," I say, with a heaven-born inspiration that breaks the ice; he is not, and he wishes the world to know it.

"Happy" he asks, scornfully. "How can I be happy? I am old and friendless. The companions of my youth have died. The men who still survive from the 'eighties dare not come to see me, for fear of displeasing the Government."

As a matter of fact, this is not quite accurate. I had the privilege of speaking with a most intelligent Egyptian patriot, and he voiced a suspicion which surprised me greatly. "Arabi!" he cried, scornfully, when I mentioned the name to him as one of the great patriots of Egypt. "Arabi is no patriot. He is the creature of the English. He sold his country to the English for the gold on which be now lives. He, and he alone, is responsible for British ooaapation. I would kill him with my own hands if I knew where to find him." It is a twisted view, of course, which only an Oriental would think of, but if it is generally held--and, so far as I can discover, it is--one can quite understand why Arabi finds himself friendless. Anyway, the idea that he is responsible for British intervention is true enough to a certain extent, for, if there had been no military revolt, then the European concert might have muddled along till this very day.
But while this thought is running through my mind Arabi is speaking energetically to the interpreter

"They have taken away my lands, these English; they have deprived me of my civil rights. I cannot vote; I cannot make a contract; I am as a dead man. This me a pension of £600 a year to support myself and my family. Why, it is only enough to feed a dog with."

"But," I venture, perhaps it is the rule that all those who took part in the rebellion should be deprived of their civil rights ?" "Not so," he replied, energetically. "Mohamed Sami was liberated, and had his civil rights restored. And if I was guilty of treason so also was Mohamed Sami, and more so." "What do you feel to day of the rising of '81 Do you still feel that you were in the right ?"

Arabi straightens himself. "Listen," he says, impressively. "and I will tell you." And this is what he told me, sitting in the twilight of the faded room, beating heavily with his stick upon his hand.

"The history of Egypt since the time of the Pyramids is a dark story. It is the history of oppression, of cruelty, of dark deeds. done openly. The Egyptians were slaves, for they had no protection from their masters. To our oppressors everything was lawful. We had no rights, no security; our wives, even, were not our own. There was corruption and and extortion everywhere. Ismail ground us to the earth.

"Now, I, a fellah, a son of the soil, saw all these evils, and, with one or two others, I would have them put right. We did not conspire, but we asked for just government. Then, one day, we were invited to the palace, and they treacherously arrested us. The army, which loved me, when it heard, came. I wrote to the British Consal for help, feeling sure that England would be on the side of justice. But no help came. I lit the torch of liberty, and England put it out, "Disappointed? Ah, indeed, you are right. We did not know what to do. And yet I would not leave the country. The French Consul offered me £500 to go to France, but I refused. I loved my native land too well.
"The whole of the country was with me for reform. We had all suffered together, and we would all have shared the good results of the triumph of right over wrong."
"But those massacres of Alexandria, when they killed men and women and little children. What of them; surely they were not in the cause of liberty?".

"No, they were terrible, and we did all in our power to repair the fault. But there was some excuse for the people. They were ignorant, they were excited, and they saw foreign warships in the bay of Alexandria. They said amongst themselves that the foreigners had come to take our country."
"Were you present at the bombardment?" I ask.
"Yes, I was there, and I did my best for my country, but we never expected to have to fight the English; we were not ready for the bombardment when it came.".
"We are very proud in England of a little ship called the Condor, which ran up under Fort Marabout. Did you see the actual thing happen ?"
"No, I did not see that; I was at the other end of the town; but they told me of it. It was a brave thing to do, for she was a little ship, they say. The captain must have been a good man."
"And what happened after that?" The fire in the old eyes dies down; I see again a very old, broken man before me.
"There was the battle, and my unprepared troops fled. I was arrested; they tried me, and sent me to Ceylon."
"Were you well treated there ?"

"Yea, they treated me very well, and, as I told you, I was far happier there than in Egypt. My prison was no prison. I could travel about the island; and when I travelled there was a special train for me. When distinguished guests came to visit the island they always wished to see me, and there was my special chair ready for me. I had a very pleasant interview with your Prince of Wales when he came to the island, I sitting in my chair and talking with him as one man to another.

"Ah, it would have been better if I had stayed there and died there. I have written again and again to Lord Cromer and the Khedive to allow me a little more money for my family. I had a hundred thousands pounds' worth of property when they took me. Now I have nothing but the six hundred pounds a year that the Government allows me. It is hard."
He is very tired, and the excitement of speaking of these things has wearied him. We rise to go.
"Tell me," I ask before we begin our final salutations, "if occupation had to come, would you prefer British, or French, or Turkish rule "

"There need have been no occupation," ha replies, impressively; "but since it must be, the English are the best masters, They are fair, they rule the country well. Yes, the English have done well what I tried to do, and, if Egypt cannot be free, we must be content that she is prosperous."
("Pall Mall Gazette")

div.head: A CHRISTIAN REFORMER OF MOHAMEDAN WOMEN.
div.p: Prince Nicholas of Montenegro lately signed an ediot ordering that henceforth no Mohamedan woman should appear in the streets with her face covered by "yashmak" or other Bort of veil. All and every Turkish woman had ja future to show the full beauty of her face to the free and happy men-subjects of his Royal Highness, just as her Christian sisters do. It is said that the Turkish women, or rather the Albanian women of Mohamedan faith, are delighted by the reform.

Unfortunately, their husbands, fathers, and brothers as stupid retrogrades are simply hor rified At a principal morque of Dulcigno a great meeting was held under the guidanos of the Principal Mufti. Learned Chadjas paad the passages from the Horan, ordering the womenfolk of the true believers never to ap pear outside their own homes without covering on head and face. They declared that, although his Royal Highness was a mighty rules, he could not change the rules established by God's great Prophet. A deputation was sent to Cettiaje to make humble representation to the Prince. But the constitutional antoorat of Montenegro answered the Koran with states- manlike conclusiveness: "What I bave said, I have said!"

Thereupon the true believers began rapidly to sell their houses and lands and emigrate with their closely and thickly veiled women to "the White Soudar on-Boyana," the ospital | of North Albania. This was throwing discredit on the princely reformer. A new edict was published declaring that every Mohamedan who is foolish enough to emigrate because of the edict on yashmaks forfeits ipso facto all his immovable property which will be then confi cited for the benefit of public charities! A German merchant of Dalcigno suggested then that the Mufti should write a Masbata, or humble petition, to the great friend of the Khalif, the mighty Padishah of the Alamani. Never a greater compliment was paid to the genins of the Kaiser than this one coming from Dalcigno of Adria! And as just now Prince Nicholas has himself received a compliment from the Kaiser in the shape of a German Minister to Cettinje, it is hoped that it will not be difficult for the friend of Pan-Islamism to save the faces of the Mohamedan women of Montenegro by saving their "yashmake."

div.head: LORD AMHERST'S EGYPTIAN
div.p: ANTIQUITIES.
PROBABLE DISPERSAL.
The heavy financial loss which Lord Amberst of Hackney has sustained will, it is understood by the "Tribune," lead to the dispersal of the famous collections at Didlington Hall.

The Oriental collection of Lord Amherst is probably only surpassed by that of the Dake of Northamberland at Alnwick, and comprises works of art and literature that are celebrated all over the world. The Egyptian collection, which has occupied more than forty years in gathering, is arranged in a special museum, and contains some of the finest mommies that have come to England, for the formation of the museam, commenced at a time when there was no restriction on the removal of antiquities from Egypt.

The most important part of the collection, however, is that of the antiquities obtained from the excavations which Professor Petrie and Mr. Howard Carter carried out for Lord Amherst at Tel-el-Amarna in 1892. The work upon the site of the remarkable city, built by the heretic Pharaoh Amenophis IV., in a o 1450, resulted in the recovery of some beautiful specimens of the unique art of the period which totally differs from that of the Theban school. Among the finest specimens are small composite statoes in alabaster and fleshcoloured jasper of the King and his young and beautiful Queen Nefereti. This city, with its beautiful temple and palace, was a species of Egyptian Versailles. One painting in the museum represents the queen with her children on her knee,and is a perfect gem of realistic art. There is a fine collection of painted wine vases, many of which are dated as to the time the wine was received. Of great importance is the pottery of foreign origin, which is now known to be of Mycenaean origin from Crete, and resembling that found by Dr. Evans at Kaossos-which is class proof at a close commercial intercourse between the zean and the Nile Valley. The papyri, which have been published by Mr. Percy Newberry, are of great impartanoe, beside several portions of the Book of the Dead,

div.head: EGYPTIAN WITCHCRAFT.
div.p: There are two of special value. The first is the report of the State trial of certain persons for entering into conspiracy with the women of the royel harem. An interesting feature of this document is the charge against the aconsed of having employed witchcraft by using wax statues to win over the women to their cause. Also remarkable is the order given to the chief conspirator to commit suicide, a form of death which, according to the Egyptian religion, entailed eternal death both in this world and the next,

Next of importance is the report of the Royal Commission which was appointed in the reign of Rameses XX, about B.c 1000, to examine all the royal tombs, and to report upon their condition, as many of them had been broken into and robbed. The report is followed by the trial of a regular band of robbers, embracing all classes of the Theban population-from priests to washerwomen.

There are also some fine Greek papyri, which have been discovered by Drs. Hunt and Grenfell, and among them is a portion of the Septuagint version of Genesis, which is certainly the oldest manuscript of the Bible known. There are several very early fragments of Gospels and St. Paul's Epistler, and a curious Apocalyptio work entitled the "Apocalypse of Issiah." There are many Coptic manuscripts, some of them of great value for the study of Church History,

It is the wish of all lovers of archaeology that this collection will not have to be dispersed, for Lord Amherst, who is a keen arobeologist, has always placed his treasures open to all Orientalists, both English and foreign. Lady Amherst has written a most useful history of Egypt, and her daughter, Lady William Cecil, has conducted some good excavations in the tombs at Assonan and published excellent descriptions of their contents.

A lady living in India sent to the local store
the other day for some lemon peel, with which to make a pudding. After she had waited some time, the following dignified note came from the Baba in charge:-
"Madam,-We have the Beecham peel, and the Cockle peel, but the peel of Eemon is out of
stock."
